learning_objective: Justify the selection of specific control structures when tradeoffs involve implementation, readability, and program performance, and explain the benefits and drawbacks of choices made.
topic: Advances in Medicine and Public Health
question_str:
{
    "Question": "Alex is passionate about medical research and is currently working on a program that can monitor and predict the spread of diseases over a geographical region. They are currently debating between two methods to track the number of infections over time in each region. Method A uses a for loop to step through each day and update the counts, while Method B uses a while loop that stops once there haven't been any changes in the counts for three consecutive days. Which method should Alex choose to use?",
    "Answer1": "Method A, because it is easier to read and understand.",
    "Answer2": "Method B, because it will use less computation time in situations where the infection numbers stabilize quickly.",
    "Answer3": "Method A, because it will ensure that all data is taken into account, irrespective of the rate of change in infection numbers.",
    "Answer4": "Method B, because it allows for more real-time analysis and can stop tracking once the numbers stabilize, hence saving computational resources.",
    "CorrectAnswer": "4",
    "Explanation": "For this application, real-time analysis is critical as it can aid in quicker decision making. Method B seems more feasible as it not only takes care of the computational efficiency but also focuses on the real time tracking and control of disease spread.",
    "code_snippet": "Method A:
action MethodA()
    for each day in days
        updateCounts()
    end
end

Method B:
action MethodB()
    integer constant = 3
    while updateCounts() and constant > 0
        constant -= 1
    end
end"
}
